title: Mobility & Exercise: Moving Toward Better Wound Healing
description: Understanding how physical activity, mobility, and exercise enhance circulation, prevent complications, and accelerate wound healing through evidence-based movement strategies.

sections.heading: The Healing Power of Movement
sections.content:
Physical activity and mobility play a vital role in your wound-healing journey. Engaging in appropriate exercises can do wonders for your wound healing. While it may seem counterintuitive to move when you have a wound—especially a painful one—the right kind of movement actually accelerates healing, prevents complications, and improves your overall well-being.

Think of your body as a network of highways delivering essential supplies to a construction site (your wound). When you're inactive, it's like those highways experiencing gridlock traffic—deliveries slow down, supplies don't arrive on time, and construction work grinds to a halt. But when you move appropriately, it's like clearing the traffic—deliveries speed up, supplies arrive abundantly, and construction (healing) proceeds efficiently.

callout.title: Evidence-Based Benefits
callout.content: Research shows that appropriate exercise can increase wound healing rates by up to 25%, reduce infection risk, prevent pressure wound development, improve blood sugar control in diabetic patients, and enhance overall quality of life during the healing process.

sections.heading: Why Exercise Is Critical for Wound Healing
sections.content: Understanding the mechanisms by which exercise promotes healing helps motivate appropriate physical activity:

subsections.content:
When you move your body, your heart pumps blood more effectively, delivering all the necessary nutrients and oxygen to the wound site. This boost in blood flow helps your body heal faster and more efficiently.

**The circulation story:**

Your blood carries the essential supplies your wound needs to heal:
• **Oxygen:** Required for cell metabolism and energy production
• **Nutrients:** Glucose, amino acids, vitamins, minerals for tissue building
• **White blood cells:** Fight infection and coordinate healing
• **Growth factors:** Chemical signals that direct healing processes
• **Platelets:** Help with blood clotting and tissue repair

When you're sedentary, blood flow becomes sluggish, like a lazy river. Exercise acts like opening a dam—blood surges through your vessels with greater force and volume, flooding your wound with healing supplies.

**Specific circulation benefits:**
• Increases cardiac output (heart pumps more blood per minute)
• Dilates blood vessels (widens highways for better flow)
• Improves microcirculation (reaches tiny capillaries in wound bed)
• Reduces blood viscosity (thinner blood flows easier)
• Stimulates angiogenesis (formation of new blood vessels)

For wounds with compromised circulation (diabetic ulcers, arterial wounds, venous ulcers), improving blood flow through exercise can be the difference between healing and non-healing.

Strong muscles around the wound area can offer better support, protecting the healing tissue, and reducing the risk of complications. It's like having a strong support team to help your body during the healing process.

**Why muscle strength matters:**

**Protective cushioning:**
Muscles and the fat they contain provide padding over bones. When muscles atrophy (waste away) from inactivity, you lose this protective layer. Bones sit closer to the skin surface, increasing pressure injury risk. This is why bedridden patients develop pressure ulcers over bony prominences.

**Functional support:**
Strong muscles support joints and allow proper movement patterns. Weak muscles lead to:
• Compensatory movement patterns (puts stress on other body parts)
• Joint instability (increases fall and injury risk)
• Difficulty with transfers (bed to chair, sit to stand)
• Dependence on others for mobility

**Metabolic benefits:**
Muscle tissue is metabolically active:
• Burns calories even at rest
• Acts as protein reservoir (body can draw amino acids from muscle for wound healing)
• Helps regulate blood sugar (muscle cells take up glucose)
• Produces myokines (proteins with healing benefits)

**Maintaining independence:**
Muscle strength allows you to:
• Reposition yourself (critical for pressure wound prevention)
• Participate in your own wound care
• Continue activities of daily living
• Maintain quality of life

For people with diabetes (a major impediment to wound healing), exercise is medicine.

**How exercise helps diabetes:**

**Immediate effects:**
• Muscles take up glucose from blood without needing insulin
• Blood sugar drops during and after exercise
• Increased insulin sensitivity lasts 24-48 hours

**Long-term effects:**
• Improves overall blood sugar control (lowers HbA1c)
• Reduces insulin resistance
• Helps with weight management
• Improves circulation (combats diabetic vascular damage)

**Why this matters for wound healing:**
High blood sugar impairs healing by:
• Damaging blood vessels (reduces nutrient delivery)
• Impairing white blood cell function (increased infection risk)
• Slowing collagen formation (weaker tissue repair)
• Promoting inflammation (delays healing phases)

By improving blood sugar control, exercise directly addresses these healing barriers.

For venous leg ulcers and other wounds complicated by swelling, movement is essential.

**The muscle pump mechanism:**

Your leg muscles act as a pump for your venous system:
• When muscles contract, they squeeze veins
• This pushes blood upward toward the heart
• Valves in veins prevent backflow
• Process repeats with each muscle contraction

When you're inactive:
• The muscle pump doesn't work
• Blood pools in leg veins
• Pressure builds
• Fluid leaks into tissues (edema)
• Swelling stretches skin and impairs healing

When you move:
• Muscle pump activates
• Blood flows back toward heart
• Venous pressure decreases
• Edema resolves
• Wounds heal better

**Walking is particularly effective** for activating the calf muscle pump—sometimes called your 'second heart.'

Regular moderate exercise strengthens your immune system's ability to fight wound infections and coordinate healing.

**Immune benefits:**
• Increases circulation of immune cells (they patrol more effectively)
• Enhances white blood cell function
• Reduces chronic inflammation (paradoxically, while acute inflammation is needed for healing, chronic inflammation impairs it)
• Improves antibody response
• Reduces stress hormones that suppress immunity

**The sweet spot:**
Moderate exercise boosts immunity. However, excessive intense exercise can temporarily suppress immunity. For wound healing, moderate activity is ideal.

When you exercise, your body releases endorphins. I like to call them 'feel-good' chemicals. Endorphins can boost your mood and help you stay positive during your healing process, and having a positive mindset is just like having a cheerleader encouraging you and your body to heal.

**Psychological benefits of exercise:**

**Mood enhancement:**
• Endorphin release (natural opioids)
• Increased serotonin and dopamine
• Reduced anxiety and depression
• Improved self-efficacy (feeling capable)

**Stress reduction:**
• Lowers cortisol (stress hormone that impairs healing)
• Provides mental distraction from pain and worry
• Improves sleep quality
• Gives sense of control over situation

**Why mental health matters for healing:**
Depression and anxiety have been shown to:
• Delay wound healing
• Increase pain perception
• Reduce treatment adherence
• Impair immune function
• Worsen outcomes

By improving mental well-being, exercise indirectly supports physical healing.

sections.heading: Types of Beneficial Exercise for Wound Healing
sections.content: Different types of exercise provide different benefits. The ideal exercise program includes a variety:

subsections.content:
**What they are:** Gentle movements that take joints through their full arc of movement

**Purpose:**
• Prevent joint stiffness and contractures (permanent joint tightening)
• Maintain flexibility
• Promote circulation
• Preserve function

**When they're essential:**
• During bedrest or limited mobility
• Around wounds near joints
• After surgery
• In elderly or debilitated patients
• For pressure wound prevention

**Types of ROM:**

**Passive ROM:**
• Someone else moves your joints for you
• Used when you can't move independently
• Caregiver, nurse, or physical therapist performs movements
• Still provides circulation and flexibility benefits

**Active-assisted ROM:**
• You move with help from someone or using your other hand
• Partial independence
• Gradually builds strength

**Active ROM:**
• You move joints yourself without assistance
• Full independence
• Provides strength and circulation benefits

**Examples of ROM exercises:**
• Ankle circles and pumps (critical for leg circulation)
• Shoulder rolls and arm circles
• Hip and knee bending
• Neck rotations
• Finger and wrist movements
• Toe curls and spreads

**How to perform:**
• Slow, gentle, controlled movements
• Move through full arc without pain
• 10-15 repetitions per joint
• 2-3 times daily
• Stop if pain occurs

**What they are:** Sustained lengthening of muscles and soft tissues

**Purpose:**
• Increase flexibility
• Prevent contractures
• Reduce muscle tension
• Improve circulation
• Enhance relaxation

**Benefits for wound healing:**
• Keeps muscles and skin supple around wound
• Prevents tightness that could stress wound edges
• Promotes blood flow to tissues
• Reduces pain from muscle tension
• Maintains functional mobility

**Safe stretching technique:**
• Warm up first (gentle movement or warm compress)
• Stretch slowly to point of mild tension (not pain)
• Hold stretch 15-30 seconds
• Breathe slowly and deeply
• Relax into the stretch
• Never bounce or force
• Repeat 2-4 times per muscle group

**Important:** Avoid aggressive stretching near wounds, especially surgical wounds or burns where excessive pulling could damage healing tissue.

**Why walking is the gold standard:**

Walking is the single most beneficial exercise for most wound patients because it:
• Activates the calf muscle pump (improves venous circulation)
• Promotes overall cardiovascular circulation
• Helps control blood sugar
• Strengthens multiple muscle groups
• Prevents pressure wounds (gets you out of bed/chair)
• Improves mood and mental outlook
• Requires no equipment
• Can be done almost anywhere
• Easily adjustable intensity

**Walking for specific wound types:**

**Venous leg ulcers:** Walking is ESSENTIAL
• Activates muscle pump to reduce venous pressure
• Reduces edema
• May be single most important intervention
• Goal: Walk as much as tolerated, even short frequent walks

**Pressure injuries:** Walking prevents worsening
• Gets you out of bed or chair
• Redistributes pressure
• Improves overall circulation
• Maintains muscle strength

**Diabetic foot ulcers:** Walking requires caution
• May need offloading device (special shoe/boot)
• Absolutely must not walk on unprotected diabetic foot wound
• Once properly offloaded, walking benefits still apply
• Non-weight-bearing exercise alternatives may be needed

**How to start a walking program:**

**Week 1-2:** Establish baseline
• Walk 5-10 minutes 2-3 times daily
• Flat, even surfaces
• Comfortable pace (able to talk while walking)
• Use assistive device if needed (cane, walker)

**Week 3-4:** Gradual increase
• Add 2-3 minutes to each walk
• Increase frequency if tolerated
• Begin to notice which times of day feel best

**Week 5+:** Build endurance
• Continue adding time gradually
• Goal: 20-30 minutes most days
• Can break into multiple shorter walks if needed

**Listen to your body:**
• Some mild muscle fatigue is normal
• Sharp pain, dizziness, or shortness of breath means STOP
• Rest if needed, then resume at lower intensity

**Benefits of water exercise:**
• Buoyancy reduces stress on joints and wounds
• Resistance in all directions strengthens muscles
• Hydrostatic pressure reduces swelling
• Cool water can be soothing
• Low-impact (safe for people with arthritis or mobility issues)

**Important restrictions:**
• Wound MUST be completely healed before swimming in pools/lakes
• Open wounds + water = HIGH infection risk
• Chlorine and pool chemicals can damage healing tissue
• Exception: Some physical therapy pools use specialized sterile water for water-walking therapy with waterproof dressings

**Once wounds are healed:**
Swimming and water aerobics are excellent for:
• Maintaining fitness during healing
• Transitioning back to full activity
• Long-term health and preventing recurrence

**What it is:** Exercise using resistance (weights, bands, body weight) to build muscle strength

**Benefits:**
• Builds and maintains muscle mass
• Improves functional strength
• Increases metabolic rate
• Improves bone density
• Enhances independence

**For wound healing:**
Focus on:
• Light to moderate resistance
• Muscles around (but not directly over) wound
• Functional movements (sit-to-stand, step-ups, etc.)
• Gradual progression

**Examples:**
• Chair stands (sit-to-stand exercises)
• Wall push-ups
• Resistance band exercises
• Light hand weights
• Leg lifts

**Safety:**
• Avoid exercises that put direct pressure on wound
• Don't hold breath (can spike blood pressure)
• Start light, progress slowly
• Supervision recommended initially

subsections.subheading: Bed and Chair Exercises (For Limited Mobility)
subsections.content:
For patients confined to bed or chair, exercise is still possible and important:

**Bed exercises:**
• Ankle pumps (point toes toward ceiling, then toward end of bed)
• Leg slides (bend knee, sliding foot toward buttocks)
• Arm raises
• Shoulder shrugs
• Pelvic tilts
• Deep breathing exercises
• Gluteal squeezes

**Chair exercises:**
• Seated marching
• Seated leg extensions
• Arm circles
• Seated twists
• Seated forward bends
• Toe taps and heel raises
• Hand and finger exercises

**Frequency:** 2-4 times daily, 10-15 repetitions each

**Why they matter:**
Even these simple exercises:
• Maintain some muscle mass
• Promote circulation
• Prevent complete deconditioning
• Preserve joint mobility
• Provide mental stimulation

sections.heading: Tailoring Exercise to Your Specific Wound
sections.content: It's important to remember that each person's situation is unique. This is why it's essential to tailor your exercise routine to your specific wound type and overall health condition. Your healthcare provider can guide you on which exercises are best for you.

subsections.content:
**Exercise goals:**
• Get out of bed/chair regularly
• Maintain muscle mass for pressure redistribution
• Preserve ability to reposition self
• Prevent additional pressure wounds

**Recommended exercises:**
• Regular position changes (every 2 hours minimum)
• Bed/chair exercises when unable to ambulate
• Walking as much as tolerated
• Progressive mobility (bed → chair → standing → walking)
• Strengthening exercises for arms and legs

**Cautions:**
• Avoid pressure on affected area during exercise
• Use pressure-relieving cushions during chair exercises
• Don't exercise on bed/chair for so long that pressure wound worsens

**Exercise goals:**
• Improve blood sugar control
• Enhance circulation
• Maintain non-wounded leg strength
• Prevent additional ulcers

**Critical rule: NO WEIGHT-BEARING on unprotected diabetic foot wound**

**Recommended exercises:**
• Upper body exercises (seated or standing)
• Non-weight-bearing leg exercises (seated leg lifts, ankle pumps)
• Walking ONLY with proper offloading device (special boot/shoe)
• Swimming (once wound healed)
• Recumbent bike or arm cycle ergometer

**Cautions:**
• NEVER walk barefoot with diabetic foot wound
• Check feet before and after exercise for new injuries
• Proper footwear essential
• Monitor blood sugar (exercise lowers it)

**Exercise goals:**
• Activate calf muscle pump
• Reduce venous pressure and edema
• Improve venous return

**Recommended exercises:**
• Walking (MOST IMPORTANT)
• Ankle pumps (flex and point feet)
• Calf raises
• Leg elevation combined with ankle exercises
• Chair exercises that involve leg movement

**The prescription:**
Walk as much as possible—this is often THE most effective treatment for venous ulcers. Even multiple short walks (5-10 minutes) throughout the day are beneficial.

**Cautions:**
• Wear compression stockings during exercise (if prescribed)
• Elevate legs after exercise
• Avoid prolonged standing still (standing without moving doesn't help and may worsen edema)

**Exercise goals:**
• Prevent complications (blood clots, pneumonia)
• Maintain strength
• Return to normal function
• Promote healing

**Timeline approach:**

**Days 1-3 post-surgery:**
• Deep breathing and coughing exercises
• Ankle pumps
• Passive and gentle active ROM
• Short walks (even just to bathroom)

**Days 4-14:**
• Increase walking distance gradually
• Gentle stretching (avoiding surgical site)
• ROM exercises
• Follow surgeon's restrictions

**Weeks 2-6:**
• Progressive return to normal activities
• May start light resistance exercises
• Gradually increase intensity

**Cautions:**
• Follow surgeon's specific restrictions
• Avoid lifting restrictions (typically 10-15 lbs initially)
• Don't pull on incision
• Stop if incision pain increases or opens
• Support incision during coughing/sneezing

**Exercise goals:**
• Improve circulation through collateral vessel development
• Increase walking distance before pain (claudication)
• Enhance overall cardiovascular health

**Recommended exercises:**
• Walking to the point of mild to moderate pain, rest, repeat
• This 'claudication therapy' helps body develop alternate blood vessel routes
• Gentle ankle and foot exercises
• Upper body exercises

**Cautions:**
• May have limited exercise tolerance due to circulation
• Need medical clearance before starting program
• Monitor for severe pain, pallor, coldness
• May need supervised exercise program initially

sections.heading: Creating Your Personal Exercise Plan
sections.content: As you progress in your healing journey, it's so important to gradually increase your activity level. Listen to your body and follow your healthcare provider's recommendations. It's like taking small steps toward your goal of better healing and overall well-being.

subsections.content:
Before starting any exercise program, consult your healthcare provider, especially if you have:
• Heart disease
• Diabetes
• Recent surgery
• Severe mobility limitations
• Foot wounds (need offloading assessment)
• Dizziness or balance problems

Your provider can:
• Clear you for exercise or identify restrictions
• Recommend specific exercises for your wound type
• Refer you to physical therapy if needed
• Adjust medications if necessary (exercise lowers blood sugar)

**The biggest mistake:** Doing too much too soon

**Better approach:**
• Start with less than you think you can do
• Build gradually over weeks
• Some soreness is normal; pain is a warning signal
• Rest days are important

**Beginner goals:**
• 5-10 minutes of gentle movement 2-3 times daily
• ROM exercises for all major joints
• Short walks on level surfaces
• Focus on consistency over intensity

**Progressive overload principle:** Gradually increase exercise demands

**How to progress:**
• Increase duration before intensity (walk longer before walking faster)
• Add 10-20% more time/repetitions per week
• If you can't talk while exercising, slow down
• If exercise is too easy, increase slightly

**Signs you're progressing appropriately:**
• Mild muscle fatigue that resolves with rest
• Feeling stronger over time
• Increased endurance
• Better mood and energy
• Wound showing healing progress

**Track these indicators:**

**Wound response:**
• Is wound healing progressing?
• Any increase in drainage, redness, or pain?
• Any wound opening or breakdown?

**Physical response:**
• Fatigue level (should decrease over time)
• Pain during and after exercise
• Ability to complete activities of daily living
• Sleep quality

**Overall health:**
• Blood sugar levels (for diabetics)
• Swelling in legs
• Mood and motivation
• Appetite

**Concerning signs (stop and notify provider):**
• Wound worsening or opening
• Severe pain
• Excessive fatigue
• Dizziness or lightheadedness
• Chest pain or severe shortness of breath
• New numbness or weakness

**The key to success:** Regular, consistent moderate exercise beats occasional intense exercise

**Building habits:**
• Exercise at same time each day
• Link to existing routine (after meals, before bed)
• Set reminders
• Track progress (simple calendar check marks)
• Find exercise buddy for accountability
• Celebrate milestones

**On difficult days:**
• Some exercise is better than none
• Do what you can without guilt
• Resume normal routine next day
• Don't let one missed day derail you

sections.heading: Safety Considerations
sections.content: Exercise should help healing, not hinder it. Keep these safety principles in mind:

subsections.content:
• Proper dressing securely in place
• Offloading devices for foot wounds
• Avoid direct pressure or friction on wound
• Clean and re-dress wound after exercise if needed
• Monitor for any signs of wound deterioration

• Use assistive devices (cane, walker) if balance is impaired
• Clear exercise area of tripping hazards
• Good lighting
• Non-slip footwear
• Exercise near sturdy furniture or wall for support
• Consider balance training exercises
• Have someone nearby if fall risk is high

**Diabetes:**
• Check blood sugar before exercise
• Have fast-acting sugar available for hypoglycemia
• May need medication adjustment
• Exercise 1-2 hours after meals (better blood sugar)

**Heart disease:**
• Monitor heart rate and symptoms
• Stop if chest pain, severe shortness of breath, or dizziness
• Know your target heart rate range
• Warm up and cool down important

**Arthritis:**
• Low-impact activities
• Avoid exercises that worsen joint pain
• May need to exercise when medication is most effective
• Ice afterwards if joints swell

**Stop exercising and rest if you experience:**
• Severe shortness of breath
• Chest pain or pressure
• Dizziness or lightheadedness
• Nausea
• Severe fatigue
• Wound pain or bleeding
• Numbness or tingling

**Seek immediate medical care if:**
• Chest pain doesn't resolve with rest
• Severe difficulty breathing
• Loss of consciousness
• Severe bleeding from wound
• Sudden weakness or numbness

sections.heading: Working with Healthcare Professionals
sections.content: You don't have to create an exercise plan alone:

subsections.content:
**What they do:**
• Assess your current mobility and strength
• Create individualized exercise programs
• Teach proper exercise technique
• Progress your program safely
• Address specific functional goals
• Provide assistive devices if needed

**When to request PT:**
• Significant mobility limitations
• Need help with safe exercise progression
• Balance or fall risk concerns
• Unsure how to exercise with your specific wound

**What they do:**
• Focus on activities of daily living
• Adaptive techniques for self-care
• Energy conservation strategies
• Home safety assessments
• Equipment recommendations

**When to request OT:**
• Difficulty with bathing, dressing, etc.
• Need strategies to manage fatigue
• Home modifications needed

**What they do:**
• Monitor wound response to exercise
• Adjust offloading devices
• Ensure exercise plan compatible with wound healing
• Coordinate with PT/OT

**Communication is key:**
Tell your wound care provider about your exercise plan and any wound changes you notice during or after exercise.

sections.heading: The Mind-Body Connection
sections.content:
Your journey to healing involves not just your body but also your mind, and exercise can contribute to your overall well-being and positive mindset.

Remember:
• **Movement is medicine** - appropriate exercise accelerates healing
• **Start where you are** - every journey begins with a single step
• **Progress, not perfection** - consistency matters more than intensity
• **Listen to your body** - it tells you what it needs
• **Celebrate small victories** - walking 5 minutes more than last week is success
• **You're not alone** - healthcare professionals can guide you

By incorporating gentle range-of-motion exercises, stretching, and low-impact activities into your daily routine, you're giving your body the support it needs. Remember to tailor your exercises to your specific situation and gradually increase your activity level as you heal.

faqs.question: Can exercise actually make my wound heal faster?
faqs.answer: Yes. Research shows that appropriate exercise can increase wound healing rates by up to 25% through multiple mechanisms: improved circulation delivers more oxygen and nutrients to the wound, enhanced blood sugar control (especially important for diabetics), reduced swelling through muscle pump activation, stronger immune function, and improved mood and stress reduction. The key is 'appropriate'—too little or too much can both be problematic. Moderate, consistent exercise tailored to your wound type provides maximum benefit.

faqs.question: I have a diabetic foot ulcer. Can I walk?
faqs.answer: NEVER walk on an unprotected diabetic foot wound—this is critical. However, with proper offloading (special boot or shoe that removes pressure from the wound), walking may be allowed and beneficial. Your podiatrist or wound care specialist must assess whether walking is safe and provide appropriate offloading device. Without proper protection, walking on a diabetic foot ulcer will make it worse and could lead to serious complications. Upper body exercises and non-weight-bearing leg exercises are safe alternatives while the foot heals.

faqs.question: My wound hurts when I exercise. Should I stop?
faqs.answer: Distinguish between wound pain and muscle fatigue. Mild muscle fatigue/soreness is normal and okay. However, STOP if you experience: sharp pain from the wound itself, increased wound drainage or bleeding, wound edges pulling apart, severe pain that doesn't resolve with rest, or dizziness/chest pain. After stopping, contact your healthcare provider. The exercise may need modification (different type, lower intensity, better wound protection) rather than complete discontinuation. Often adjustments allow you to continue exercising safely.

faqs.question: I'm confined to bed or a wheelchair. Can I still exercise?
faqs.answer: Absolutely yes, and it's especially important! Even bed-bound or wheelchair-bound patients can and should exercise. Options include: ankle pumps and leg slides in bed, arm exercises, seated exercises in wheelchair, resistance band exercises, range-of-motion exercises for all joints, and deep breathing exercises. These prevent muscle wasting, maintain joint mobility, promote circulation, prevent additional pressure wounds, and preserve whatever function you have. Even small amounts of movement provide significant benefits. Ask for physical therapy referral for individualized bed/chair exercise program.

faqs.question: How much exercise is too much?
faqs.answer: Warning signs of over-exercising: wound worsening or opening, excessive fatigue that doesn't resolve with rest, inability to complete normal daily activities, decreasing performance over time instead of improving, persistent muscle soreness, disrupted sleep, or loss of appetite. For wound healing, moderate is better than intense. If you can't hold a conversation while exercising, you're working too hard. Start conservatively and increase gradually (10-20% more per week). Rest days are important—your body heals and strengthens during rest. When in doubt, consult your healthcare provider.

faqs.question: When can I return to my normal exercise routine after surgery?
faqs.answer: This depends entirely on the surgery type and your individual healing. General guidelines: light walking usually allowed within days, most normal activities resume at 2-4 weeks, full return to vigorous exercise often 6-8 weeks or longer, and heavy lifting restrictions typically 4-6 weeks. However, YOUR surgeon provides the timeline for YOUR specific surgery. Some procedures (heart surgery, abdominal surgery) require longer healing. Others (minor skin procedures) allow quicker return. Always follow your surgeon's specific instructions. Returning to exercise too soon risks wound dehiscence (opening), hernias, or other serious complications.
